learning_objective: Explain how abstractions hide the underlying implementation details of computing systems embedded in everyday objects.
question_str:
{
    "Question": "Alex has been tasked with coding an application that tracks food intake and calculates nutritional values to help encourage healthier eating habits. In designing this application, Alex decides to use abstractions for several tasks, including 'CalculateCalories', 'AddFoodItem', and 'DisplayNutritionReport'. Which of the following represents the best use of abstraction?",
    "Answer1": "Alex writes detailed methods to calculate the caloric value and nutritional content of each individual food type.",
    "Answer2": "Alex has separate 'CalculateCalories' procedures for different meals: breakfast, lunch, dinner, and snacks.",
    "Answer3": "Alex creates a universal method to 'CalculateCalories' that can be applied to any food item entered into the system.",
    "Answer4": "Alex builds a separate application to process and analyse the user's food photo instead of writing a code to identify food items.",
    "CorrectAnswer": "3",
    "Explanation": "Abstraction is the process of hiding the complexity of the complete system and exposing only the necessary parts. In this case, a universal 'CalculateCalories' function is a perfect example of abstraction, as it allows Alex to handle any kind of food input without specifying the calculation for each individual food type.",
    "code_snippet": "class Food

    action CalculateCalories(FoodItem item)
        integer calories = item.GetCaloricValue()
        return calories
    end

    action AddFoodItem(FoodItem item)
        // TODO: Add code to add item to list of consumed foods
    end

    action DisplayNutritionReport()
        // TODO: Write code to calculate total nutrition report based on consumed foods list
    end

end

"
}
